ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Independent study in a lab.
Virtual discussion with research advisor, data analysis on the computer
I worked in my research lab and wrote a proposal and progress report.
I met with my advisor on Zoom
This class was taken asynchronously, and students met virtually with their advisors when needed.
This was mostly independent, so there wasn't a clear time and most meetings were done over zoom.

I met weekly with my advisor and a postdoctoral fellow who has helped supervise my project since the summer. On top of that meeting, the lab brackets the week with meetings. One is typically a meeting in which we workshop a paper, a project, or an idea. The other meeting is a science writing workshop. I presented work at both meetings this semester.
Thesis research

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Working independently with faculty guidance, many specific skills relevant to my topic of choice.
Senior project work
I gained more experience in doing lab work and in scientific writing.
This semester I learned how to use R studio for genetic analyses
I learned how to think up and initiate my own project, from conception to seeking IRB approval to collecting data.
Even though this semester wasn't entirely successful, I still learned a lot about evolutionary biology and the specific details of the project I was working on. It was very interesting.

I've gained a lot of confidence working with data and structuring it to address research questions. Since the spring, I've had to change my project a lot. And through research for this course (and my thesis) I've made a lot of strides in data wrangling and analysis capabilities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Had the opportunity to work on my senior project safely despite the public health circumstances -- hats off to the E&EB faculty and my PI for facilitating the process!
Being able to work independently on a project
The strengths are that students can carry out their own projects. I cannot think of any weaknesses.
Since it was largely self directed and individual, there isn't much that could be improved. Overall, the emails sent to keep us on track and with instructions were helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The asynchronous component of this class served students well for online learning during the pandemic. I also appreciate the checkpoints we had during the beginning and end of the semester.
The zoom meetings with my mentor for the project were helpful and easy to arrange.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not much of a recommendation since you'll have to take this... but it's a good class and you can make what you want of it!
If you're looking at this review, you probably need the course to graduate. However, I really recommend doing a full year of research if you can!
It's just working in the lab.
Yes, the opportunity to work one-on-one with a professor or advisor is really beneficial and allows you to apply things you've learned in the classroom in lab.
It's required for all E&EB seniors, but I would recommend this two-semester class because it gives students a bit more time to carry out their projects.
